topic.name: Expansion, Reform & Sectional Conflict
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Expansion, Reform & Sectional Conflict in History & Social Studies

objectives.objective_text: Identify Abraham Lincoln.
Name the Blue (North) and Grey (South) armies.
Identify Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant.
Identify Andrew Jackson as a soldier president.
Name the 'Trail of Tears' as a very sad march.
Identify the Veto power used by Jackson.
Identify the US getting much bigger.
Name Lewis and Clark.
Identify 'Manifest Destiny' (belief that US should go west).
Identify the country coming back together.
Name the 13th Amendment (No more slavery).
Identify the Freedman's Bureau.
Identify Harriet Tubman.
Name the North Star.
Identify Uncle Tom's Cabin (the book).
Recall that the slaves were set free.
Observe the tall hat of the President.
Recall that Native Americans were forced to move.
Observe that promises were broken.
Recall Sacagawea helping them.
Observe a map showing the US stretching to the ocean.
Recall that it was hard to be friends again.
Observe schools starting for former slaves.
Recall that slavery is when someone owns another person.
Observe that people helped slaves escape.
Summarize the Emancipation Proclamation.
Explain the Battle of Gettysburg.
Explain the surrender at Appomattox.
Defend the war as a 'New Birth of Freedom'.
Summarize the election of the 'Common Man'.
Explain the Indian Removal Act.
Explain the defiance of the Supreme Court (Worcester v. Georgia).
Defend the rights of the Cherokee based on treaties.
Summarize Jefferson buying land from Napoleon.
Explain what an expedition is.
Explain the Oregon Trail.
Defend the geopolitical necessity of controlling New Orleans.
Summarize the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments.
Explain what sharecropping was.
Explain the 'Lost Cause' myth.
Defend the rights of the Freedmen against terror.
Summarize the life of Frederick Douglass.
Explain how the Underground Railroad worked (codes/safe houses).
Explain the Fugitive Slave Act.
Defend the Imago Dei as the death knell of slavery.
Compare the Union (USA) with the Confederacy (CSA).
Interpret the Gettysburg Address.
Connect the election of 1860 to secession.
Compare the Cherokee Nation (civilized tribes) with the settlers.
Analyze the 'Corrupt Bargain' of 1824.
Interpret the Nullification Crisis (States' Rights vs. Union).
Connect the Bank War to the economy.
Compare the size of the US before and after 1803.
Analyze the constitutional dilemma of the purchase.
Interpret the impact on Native American tribes.
Connect the purchase to the Lewis and Clark scientific mission.
Compare Lincoln's plan (gentle) with Congress's plan (strict).
Analyze the rise of the KKK and Black Codes.
Interpret the impeachment of Andrew Johnson.
Connect the election of 1876 to the end of Reconstruction.
Compare the Free North with the Slave South.
Analyze the Missouri Compromise and Compromise of 1850.
Interpret the Dred Scott Decision.
Connect the cotton gin to the growth of slavery.
Evaluate Lincoln's suspension of Habeas Corpus.
Evaluate the spoils system.
Evaluate the ethics of Manifest Destiny.
Evaluate the constitutional revolution of the 14th Amendment.
Evaluate the theological arguments used for and against slavery.
Analyze the causes (State's Rights, Slavery, Economics).
Construct a strategic analysis of the Anaconda Plan.
Synthesize the social impact of the war (600,000 dead).
Construct a profile of Populism in the Jacksonian era.
Construct a map of US territorial acquisitions.
Synthesize the link between expansion and the slavery debate.
Construct an evaluation of Reconstruction: Success or Failure?
Synthesize the long shadow of Jim Crow laws.
Construct a history of the abolitionist movement (Garrison, Brown).
Synthesize the political collapse leading to secession.
Synthesize the legacy of Jackson on the modern presidency.
